questions.question: 1. What is tissue repair?
options: The replacement of damaged tissue by new healthy tissue
The accumulation of scar tissue without regeneration

questions.question: 2. Which of the following best describes regeneration?
options: Replacement of damaged tissue by connective tissue
Replacement of damaged tissue by new cells of the same type
An irreversible process leading to loss of function

questions.question: 3. What does fibrosis refer to in the context of repair?
options: Replacement of damaged tissue by connective tissue (scar formation)
Rapid cell division with no scar formation

questions.question: 4. Which type of repair occurs when the injured tissue is replaced by the same tissue type?
5. Labile cells are characterized by:
options: Slow division only under special conditions

questions.question: 6. Which of the following is an example of a labile cell?
7. Stable cells are defined as:
options: Cells that do not normally divide but can do so in response to injury
Cells that are replaced by fibrosis only

questions.question: 8. Which of the following is an example of stable cells?
9. Permanent cells are characterized by:
options: Their inability to regenerate after injury

questions.question: 10. Which cell type is considered permanent?
11. When the tissue framework remains intact after injury, healing is most likely to occur by:
12. When the tissue framework is severely damaged, repair occurs by:
options: Complete tissue necrosis with no repair

questions.question: 13. What is healing by regeneration?
options: Restoration of the injured area by new cells of the same type
Replacement of damaged tissue by fibrous scar
A process that always leads to fibrosis

questions.question: 14. What is granulation tissue?
options: Dense fibrous tissue with no cellular elements
Pink, soft, granular tissue formed by proliferating fibroblasts and new capillaries in a loose extracellular matrix
A type of permanent scar tissue

questions.question: 15. Which process is a key component of angiogenesis during repair?
16. What is the first step in the process of angiogenesis?
options: Degradation of the basement membrane of parent vessels

questions.question: 17. Fibrogenesis in wound healing involves:
options: Proliferation of fibroblasts and deposition of extracellular matrix proteins, especially collagen
Formation of granulation tissue without collagen deposition

questions.question: 18. Remodeling during wound healing refers to:
options: Maturation of granulation tissue into a dense, fibrous scar with regression of capillaries
Immediate wound contraction without collagen deposition

questions.question: 19. A mature scar is mainly composed of:
options: Dense type I collagen, few capillaries, and inactive fibroblasts
Active granulation tissue with abundant inflammatory cells

questions.question: 20. Healing by first intention (primary union) is characterized by:
options: A large amount of granulation tissue and wound contraction
Clean wound edges that are approximated, minimal granulation tissue, and a neat linear scar

questions.question: 21. Healing by second intention (secondary union) typically involves:
options: Extensive granulation tissue formation, wound contraction, and scarring

questions.question: 22. Which of the following is a systemic factor that influences wound healing?
23. Which of the following is a local factor affecting wound healing?
options: Mechanical factors such as early wound movement

questions.question: 24. Which complication may result from excessive collagen deposition during wound healing?
25. What causes wound contraction during healing?
26. Keloids are characterized by:
options: A neat, linear scar with minimal tissue overgrowth
Excess collagen deposition forming a raised scar that often recurs

questions.question: 27. Myofibroblasts contribute to wound healing by:
options: Contracting the wound and reducing its size

questions.question: 28. Which hormone can negatively affect wound healing by reducing collagen synthesis?
29. Adequate nutrition, particularly vitamin C, is essential for wound healing because it:
options: Reduces infection risk by acting as an antibiotic

questions.question: 30. Fibrosis of an inflamed joint can lead to:
31. Adhesions between serous membranes due to fibrosis can result in:
options: Formation of unwanted fibrous connections causing functional impairment

questions.question: 32. Inadequate blood supply to a wound will most likely lead to:
options: Delayed healing and poor scar formation

questions.question: 33. Infection is a local factor that can delay wound healing by:
options: Disrupting collagen deposition and prolonging inflammation

questions.question: 34. Which statement best describes regeneration?
options: Complete restoration of tissue architecture without scar formation
Replacement of damaged tissue by fibrous scar
A process that always leads to permanent loss of function

questions.question: 35. Which statement best describes fibrosis?
options: Replacement of damaged tissue by cells of the same type
Replacement of damaged tissue by connective tissue resulting in scar formation
Rapid tissue regeneration with restoration of normal function
A reversible process with no long-term consequences

questions.question: 36. What is the primary role of macrophages in tissue repair?
options: They clear debris and secrete growth factors to stimulate repair

40. Which statement is false about healing by primary union (first intention)?
options: It results in a neat linear scar
It involves minimal granulation tissue formation
It occurs in clean, uninfected wounds with approximated edges
It is characterized by exuberant granulation tissue filling the wound gap
